Updated Review:
Yes, the game is free, you have nothing to lose by downloading it, but there's still a few things I don't like about the game.
One is the poorly explained gameplay; there's not enough explanation of gameplay features and how everything actually works; how the combat is determined. For example my friend sent 300 troops against 150 expecting to win but lost. He went away from the game infuriated because of this; the game just didn't explain what happens and why battles like that are lost.
The purchasing of maps I can understand because the developer has to make a profit somehow, right? However the use of virtual currency to even host games bemuses me. You pay 5 gold to host a match, every match. This model restricts play and I believe you only get 1 gold a day for free by signing in. Any more VC you have to pay for. I also have a similar, albeit much smaller, complaint about having to pay for cosmetic avatar creation, but as it's merely cosmetic it really doesn't affect anything.
Thirdly I find there isn't enough depth to the game; the only things I can build is either a Watchtower or soldiers and there are only a few things you can do in terms of events (Fertility Festival, anyone?).

In all, I can see the appeal but I don't think it's worth my time to try and play this simply because the game doesn't explain itself well and as that has turned away my friends from playing this game, and the virtual currency has turned me away from playing this game, and as I think there isn't enough depth to satisfy me, I don't see the need to continue playing.
Perhaps it's the Europa Universalis in me speaking, but I don't recommend this game.

There are a couple things I have questions about, however. 1. How do the towers help you at all? I find that I can always see enemy troops next to my territories. Are they supposed to see enemies within a certain range? 2. When are you going to make all of the maps free? Me being a Bernie supporter, I want everything to be free. (Kidding). I remember when these games were just flash games and free apps on mobile phones, so it's funny to see where they've ended up. That's not saying that's a bad thing, this game is pretty fun. For me 20 minutes turned into 2-3 hours of games. It's cool to see the formula has been applied with a bunch of different skins that you can unlock by playing more of the game. For those of you unfamiliar with these types of games, you essentially get a certain amount of gold which you use to buy more troops. The more land you have, the more troops you can hire. To defeat your enemy you will certainly need far larger numbers of troops, generally double or so if you're attacking.

This version of the game has added in different unit types, economic upgrades and even buildings that can be built which provide bonuses to all of your troops generally in defense.

In summation, this is a fun game, just as addicting as the ones I used to play on my ipod touch in French 2 back in High school. The additional features aren't many but they are just enough to keep the formula fresh to give it a go a few more times.

Played for a little longer than some of the main reviews here, because of that, I can't give it a good review.

I like the basic gameplay; it's just like risk, if risk had more variables.  The graphics are whatever; I didn't buy it for flashing animations, I just wanted strategy play.  The multiplayer seems fine; maybe a little punishing if you're new or not that skilled in long games.

The downside here is not that it's P2W (Pay to Win), it's P4FP2P (Play for Free, Pay to Play).  As others have voiced, it has a not so great way for accruing credit for new standard content maps.  This means that single player is pretty limited to one map until you dl a few more maps through multiplayer games that are hosting them or ditch money into a game that really is only a dollar store deal at best, at the moment.  The multiplayer download maps are OK, but nothing pioneering, or even really worth going back to.

The novelty was nice for about 8 hours of play, then it just downhilled it from there.  Not enough game here to recommend spending money on, at all.

TL;DR
Play it for free first, I wouldn't ditch any money into it unless you can put at least 24 hours of solid gameplay into it and still be confident you will enjoy it in another 24 hours of solid play.

reviewText:
If you like startegy games that are revolving mostly on troop positioning, anticipating the other players' actions, diplomatic intrigues, backstabbing and clever tactics on the front, then you'll probably like this game.

It's simplistic, with the average game lasting about 40-60 turns with 2-3 minutes being fairly sufficient for all actions you might want to take. There is also the option of games with days per turn, for some more slow-paced and nerve-wracking games.

The game has a few issues here and there, such as being able to attack a player in the same turn as accepting peace treaty/alliance if currently at war if the actions are issued before the acceptance of the treaty and a few other minor things, but this review is written about a week after the launch and with the dev being online every single day and patching something every other day, I am fairly certain that they'll be quickly resolved. At the very leat, I recommend you try the game, seeing that it's free.

reviewText:
If you ever felt the urge to control something, or to conquer someone, Art of Conquest will let you do just that.
Art of Conquest is a surprisingly small game but with a very complex gameplay. Even with the help of the tutorials I was still at a lost with what to do in the beginning, but as I pushed on through my trials and errors I eventually got the hang of it. I had to form alliances or crush those who stood in my way of world domination. I almost lost sight of taking care of my people whom need to be checked on regularly.

As the rampant background music played on, I felt that I was in a constant state of war and at times felt that I only wanted/needed to do battles with my neighboring empires, instead of taking the diplomatic approach with them.

The game is visually interesting with its colour scheme for you to identify which territories are yours and which of it your neighboring empires are governing. The map is beautifully designed with its townships and oceanic scenery; it makes you feel as if you are a real strategist planning to take over the world. The overlay is easy to navigate through with its map, information and stats panes to help you to know your task at hand or to plan ahead.

Once you master the techniques of taking control of land and taking care of you kinsmen, you will find yourself playing this game over and over.

I would like to end off by saying: I am not a fan of strategy type games, but for the sake of the readers I tested out the game and was pleasantly surprised with what this game pulled off. I will definitely be playing this game for a while and when I am truly ready (oh boy), I’m jumping straight into PVP.

Love the game... All you get for the free version is the Fall of Rome map, which really only consists of Europe, some of africa, some of asia, some of the middle east but thats it.

If you want the complete world map or anything larger you will have to purchase them...

$20 for ALL maps, even future ones.
$5 ish for individual maps.

Its a better version of Risk in my honest opinion. More extensive economy/military management.

Worth the $20? depends on how much you will play.

I am an avid Risk player and I am 50/50 in purchasing or not.

Sad to admit it but the more I play it the less I like it. Its fun having 60%+ of the map and being taken over by an AI that has literally 3 territories SOMEHOW............. Somehow they went through all of my defenses and territories and hit my leader... Somehow......... even when you're pretty limited on how far you can go each turn.... Hmmmmmmmmmmmm. Love wasting my time on top of wasting my time.
